content.description: A fun, low angle arete with a massive undercling sit start.  Starting on the left side/downhill side of the arete, grab the undercling with both hands and paste your feet on the platform below.  Pull up to a left hand crimp and then the arete.  Follow crimps and good holds up the arete to a somewhat slopey topout.
content.location: This problem climbs the arete left of Barnyard Crack.  Walk down the easy slab to get off the boulder.

content.description: Looking for a quick tick? Here's a short problem with a one move crux. Sit start left of The Cooper Problem with a small right hand crimp and a bad left hand on the faint arete. Using the good left foot, pull hard and slap up to a decent slopey hold. Don't blow it and finish up the face to the top. This one used to be a little more difficult...
content.location: On the smaller of the two Barnyard Boulders, this climbs the short arete/face left of The Cooper Problem.  Downclimb off the back of the boulder.

content.description: This short problem climbs the short face to the right of The Cooper Problem with a short flake.  Did I mention that it's short?  Climb the flake up to the lip and pull over the top.
content.location: On the smaller of the two Barnyard Boulders, this problem climbs a flake to the right of The Cooper Problem.  Downclimb off the back of the boulder.

content.description: A short but somewhat fun problem that starts on the same crimps as the Cooper Problem. Instead of moving right, slap left to a crimp around the bulge, work your feet up, and top out straight up and left. Awkward and powerful.
content.location: Located on the smaller of the Barnyard Boulders.Â Start as for The Cooper Problem but move left.

content.description:
A quick face climb that might seem puzzling until you get your body position just right for the start.  Sit start as for Barnyard Crack at the base of the crack and make a long reach or deadpoint straight up to a good hold with your left hand.  Alternately, use the small crimps and make more moves to reach the good hold.  Match and power up to the slopey top before working right and mantling the lip. 

  Somewhat of an eliminate due to its proximity to the arete, but fun nonetheless.
content.location: This problem starts as for Barnyard Crack on the larger boulder of the two.  Walk down the easy slab.

content.description: An obvious arete with a juggy start and a crux finish.  Sit start with the large jug at the base of Classic Crack.  Pull up and climb the arete directly above to reach the lip and try not to do an impersonation of a beached whale as you work up over the top.
content.location: This problem climbs the arete to the right of Classic Crack.  Walk down the easy slab to get off the boulder.

content.description: This super crimpy bulge may be a lowball, but the beta is interesting and the dynamic crux is somewhat fun.  Sit start to the left on two obvious crimps.  The right crimp is smaller now than it used to be due to breakage.  Pull off the ground and slap right into better holds, then prepare to dyno up to a good three finger crimp before finishing with a very easy topout.  Warm up your fingers before touching this one and consider using a dropknee or two.  Great for solo missions, but this problem would be far better if the first half was a bit higher off the ground.
content.location: On the smaller of the two Barnyard Boulders, look for the obvious crimpy bulge.  Downclimb the back of the boulder.

content.description:
Start on the right/low end of the crack on a juggy hold with a really good foot (yes a good foot at pawtuckaway, but dont get your hopes up for more)... Traverse up and left to a good but tiny crimp, the feet become miserable smears and you continue left along the seam past a very small pod or 2 in the crack that serve as sloping crimps... From here finish with a reach to the end...  

  I think its V2 for tall folks and a little harder for shorter types... enjoy...
content.location: This is the nice left leaning seam across from Ride the Lightning (V6)...

content.description: A nice little diversion for those that have the ups.  Grab the big jug in the middle of the Barnyard Crack and set your feet.  Now fly straight up to the slopers at the lip with one, two, or three hands and hope that friction is on your side.  A fun, slopey topout awaits and might get ugly for some.
content.location: This problem starts on the jug in the middle of Barnyard Crack on the larger boulder of the two.  Walk down the easy slab.

content.description:
Though This problem in not in the guide book i don't know why... It is a great problem for just about anyone... I have used it in my warm up circut and im sure newer boulderers would love to work to send it as it is not too hard not too high and really fun... 

  Sit start down and left then climb the right angling crack to the top out... Though some crack skills help you can get by without...
content.location: On the other side of Classic Crack... Just walk around the boulder and check out the right angling crack...

content.description: The Barnyard Boulders are often climbed on, although these two boulders are obviously absent from the guidebook for reasons unknown.  The small cluster of problems range from V0 to V8 with the majority of them being under V3 and is a great place for a beginner or a warmup.  Mostly known for their diagonal cracks, these boulders also offer a few aretes, a fun sloper dyno, and some crimpy face climbs.  The landings are all flat, youÂll never fall too far, and not surprisingly, thereÂs usually chalk on everything.
